01.text: Jesus continues to teach his disciples in his Sermon on the Mount, which began in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:05:01|5:3]]. In this section, Jesus addresses the "acts of righteousness" of alms, prayer, and fasting.
Jesus is talking to a group of people about what might happen to them as individuals. All "you" and "your" are plural.

01.ref: before people to be seen by them
01.text: It is implied that those who see the person will honor him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "in front of people just so that they can see you and give you honor for what you have done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

01.ref: do not sound a trumpet before yourself
01.text: This metaphor means to do something that purposefully gets people's attention. AT: "do not draw attention to yourself like someone who plays a loud trumpet in a crowd" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"I tell you the truth." This phrase adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

03.text: Jesus continues to teach his disciples about alms.
Jesus is talking to a group of people about what might happen to them as individuals. All "you" and "your" are plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

03.ref: do not let your left hand know what your right hand is doing
03.text: This is a metaphor for total secrecy. Just as hands usually work together and can be said to "know" what each other is doing at all times, you should not let even those closest to you know when you are giving to the poor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

03.ref: your gift may be given in secret
03.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "you can give to the poor without other people knowing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

05.text: Jesus begins to teach about prayer.

Jesus is talking to a group of people about what might happen to them as individuals. All "you" and "your" in verses 5 and 7 are plural; in verse 6 they are singular, but you may have to translate them as plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

05.ref: so that they may be seen by people
05.text: It is implied that those who see them will give them honor. This can be stated in active form. AT: "so that people will see them and give them honor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"I tell you the truth." This phrase adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

05.ref: enter your inner chamber. Shut the door
05.text: "go to a private place" or "go where you can be alone"
Possible meanings are 1) no one can see God, or 2) God is in that private place with the person praying.
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

05.ref: your Father who sees in secret
05.text: "your Father will see what you do in private and"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "their false gods will hear them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

08.text: Jesus is talking to a group of people about what might happen to them as individuals. He speaks to them as a group in the plural as far as "pray like this." All occurrences of "your" after "Heavenly Father" are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
Here "name" refers to God himself. AT: "make everyone honor you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "kingdom" refers to God's rule as king. AT: "May you rule over everyone and everything completely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

08.ref: May your will be done on earth as it is in heaven
08.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "may everything on earth happen in accordance with your will as everything in heaven does" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

11.text: All instances of "we," "us," and "our" refer to the crowd that Jesus is addressing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Here "bread" refers to food in general. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
A debt is what one person owes another. This is a metaphor for sins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
A debtor is a person who owes debts to another. This is a metaphor for sinners. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

11.ref: Do not bring us into temptation
11.text: The word "temptation," an abstract noun, can be expressed as a verb. AT: "Do not let anything tempt us" or "Do not let anything cause us to desire to sin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

14.text: All instances of "you" and "your" are plural. However, Jesus is telling them what will happen to them as individuals if each person does not forgive others. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

16.text: Jesus begins to teach about fasting.

Jesus is talking to a group of people about what might happen to them as individuals. All occurrences of "you" and "your" in verses 17 and 18 are singular, but you may want to translate them as plural to match the plural "you" in verse 16. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
The hypocrites would not wash their faces or comb their hair. They did this purposely to draw attention to themselves so that people would see them and give them honor for fasting.
"I tell you the truth." This phrase adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

"put oil in your hair" or "groom your hair." To "anoint" the head here is to take normal care of one's hair. It has nothing to do with "Christ" meaning "anointed one." Jesus means that people should look the same whether they are fasting or not.
Possible meanings are 1) no one can see God, or 2) God is in that private place with the person praying. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:06:05|6:6]].
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
"who sees what you do in private." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:06:05|6:6]].

19.text: Jesus begins to teach about money and possessions.

Jesus is talking to a group of people about what might happen to them as individuals. The instances of "you" and "your" are plural, except in verse 21, where they are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
a small, flying insect that destroys cloth
a brown substance that forms on metals

19.ref: store up for yourselves treasures in heaven
19.text: This is a metaphor that means do good things on earth so God will reward you in heaven. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

19.ref: there will your heart be also
19.text: Here "heart" means a person's thoughts and interests. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

22.text: Jesus is talking to a group of people about what might happen to them as individuals. The instances of "you" and "your" are all singular, but you may need to translate them as plurals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

22.ref: The eye is the lamp of the body ... how great is that darkness
22.text: This compares healthy eyes that allow a person to see to diseased eyes that cause a person to be blind. This is a metaphor referring to spiritual health. Often Jewish people used the phrase "bad eye" to refer to greed. The meaning is: if a person is completely devoted to God and sees things the way he does, then they are doing what is right. If a person is greedy for more, then he is doing what is evil. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

22.ref: The eye is the lamp of the body
22.text: This metaphor means the eyes allow a person to see just as a lamp helps a person see in the dark. AT: "Like a lamp, the eye allows you to see things clearly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
You may have to translate this as plural, "eyes."
This does not refer to magic. Jewish people often used this as a metaphor for someone who is greedy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

22.ref: for either he will hate the one and love the other, or else he will be devoted to one and despise the other
22.text: Both of these phrases mean basically the same thing. They emphasize that a person cannot love and be devoted both to God and money at the same time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

22.ref: You cannot serve God and wealth
22.text: "You cannot love God and money at the same time"

25.text: Here the instances of "you" and "your" are all plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.
Jesus is talking to a group of people about what might happen to them as individuals.

25.ref: is not life more than food, and the body more than clothes?
25.text: Jesus uses a question to teach the people. AT: "obviously life is more than what you eat, and your body is more than what you wear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

25.ref: Are you not more valuable than they are?
25.text: Jesus uses a question to teach the people. AT: "Obviously you are more valuable than birds." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

27.text: Jesus is talking to a group of people about what might happen to them as individuals. All instances of "you" and "your" are plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

27.ref: Which one of you by being anxious can add one cubit to his lifespan?
27.text: Jesus uses a question to teach the people. AT: "None of you can, just by worrying, add years to your life. You cannot add even one minute to your life! So you should not worry about things you need." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

A cubit is a measure of a little less than half a meter. Here it is a metaphor for adding time to how long a person will live. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bdistance]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

27.ref: Why are you anxious about clothing?
27.text: Jesus uses a question to teach the people. AT: "You should not be worried about what you will wear." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This adds emphasis to what Jesus says next.

27.ref: was not clothed like one of these
27.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "did not wear clothes that are as beautiful as these lilies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

30.text: Jesus is talking to a group of people about what might happen to them as individuals. The instances of "you" and "your" are plural.
This is a metaphor that means God makes the flowers beautiful. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
If your language has a word that includes "grass" and the word you used for "lilies" in the previous verse, you can use it here.

The Jews at that time used grass in their fires to cook their food. This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone throws it into a fire" or "someone burns it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

30.ref: how much more will he clothe you ... faith?
30.text: Jesus is using a question to teach the people. AT: "he will certainly clothe you ... faith" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"you who have such little faith." Jesus is scolding the people because they have little faith in God.

32.ref: For the Gentiles search for these things
32.text: "for the Gentiles are concerned about what they will eat, drink, and wear"

32.ref: your heavenly Father knows that you need them
32.text: Jesus is implying that God will make sure their basic needs are met.
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

32.ref: seek first his kingdom and his righteousness
32.text: Here "kingdom" refers to God's rule as king. AT: "concern yourselves with serving God, who is your king, and doing what is right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

32.ref: all these things will be given to you
32.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will provide all these things for you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

32.ref: tomorrow will be anxious for itself
32.text: Jesus is describing "tomorrow" as if it is a person who can worry. Jesus means that a person will have enough to worry about when the next day comes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
